questions.text: A 30 yrs male came to the casualty with extensive third-degree burns, he complained of nausea, headache and was irritable. He is hypotensive. His lab investigation is: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypovolemic hyponatremia This is a patient with burns, with massive fluid loss from the skin. Burns cause increases in vascular permeability and a reduction in oncotic pressure the ECFV. This leads to a state of combined salt and water loss, leading to contraction of the ECFV – Hypovolemic hyponatremia . ( Option A ) Features of Hypovolemia are seen in this patient in the form of nausea, headache and hypotension. Hyponatremia is defined as a plasma Na+ < 135Mm Lab report here shows that. (Na = 120)

Highyeild:

(hypoalbuminemia) altering Starling forces, resulting in excessive “third spacing ” of Third spacing also occurs in Sepsis Pancreatitis Nutritional hypoalbuminemia Peritonitis Evaporation of water from the skin and respiratory tract (so-called “ insensible losses ”) is typically 500–650 mL/d .

Extraedge:

Thiazides do not inhibit the renal concentrating mechanism Loop diuretics blunt the renal concentrating mechanism

questions.text: An 80 yrs male came to a casualty with a complaint of chronic diarrhoea with a history of irritable bowel syndrome. His lab investigation is as follows: What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypovolemic hyponatremia This is a patient with IBS with fluid loss in the form of diarrhoea. This leads to a state of combined salt and water loss, leading to contraction of the ECFV – Hypovolemic hyponatremia . ( Option A ) Diarrhoea is an extra-renal cause of it. Hyponatremia is defined as a plasma Na+ < 135Mm Lab report here shows that. (Na = 128)

Highyeild:

Non-renal causes (Gastrointestinal) Vomiting, Diarrhoea Tube drainage

Extraedge:

AVP preserves Blood pressure via vascular and baroreceptor V1A receptors Increases water reabsorption via renal V2 receptors

questions.text: A 30 yrs male came to the casualty with nausea, vomiting, lethargy and headache. Laboratory examinations revealed hypernatremia. The consultant asked the resident on duty to calculate the free water deficit of this patient. Which of the following is the correct mathematical expression to calculate the same?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

[(na-140)/140]*total body water(tbw) Free-water deficit: The Free water deficit is the amount of free water a patient has lost. Calculated by: [(Na+ – 140)/140] × TBW Total-body water (TBW) → 50% of body weight in women and 60% in men. Results in hypernatremia. Hypernatremia is defined as plasma Na+ concentration of >145 mM It is imperative to correct hypernatremia slowly to avoid cerebral oedema, typically replacing the calculated free water deficit.

Highyeild:

Free water deficit is not a static value. Free water deficit doesn’t take into account ongoing water losses.

Extraedge:

The free water clearance tells us the ongoing water losses

questions.text: A 60 yrs male presented with an acute onset of a confusional state and drowsiness. He had a history of colonoscopy preparation in view of irritable bowel syndrome. His lab investigation is as follows: What will be the next line of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypertonic saline infusion Patients of IBS after colonic preparation would likely have diarrhoea. Lab reports s/o hyponatremia (< 121 mEq/L) Symptomatology s/o Acute hyponatremia . Treatment with hypertonic saline is essential in symptomatic patients. Treatment with hypertonic 3% saline 3% NS contains 513mM of Na and Cl. As an infusion : Increase plasma Na+ concentration by 1–2 mM/h to a total of 4–6 Mm As bolus : 100 mL of hypertonic saline rapidly improves both serum sodium and mental status.

Highyeild:

Na+ deficit = 0.6 × body weight × (target plasma Na+ concentration – starting plasma Na+ concentration) Plasma Na+ concentration should be monitored every 2–4 h

Extraedge:

3% NS bolus is more effective than infusion Type of respiratory failure seen: Hypercapnic respiratory failure

questions.text: A 60 yrs male presented to casualty with lethargy, nausea and headache. He was diagnosed with hyponatremia and was started on Conivaptan. What is the mechanism of action of the above drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

V1a/v2 avp(vasopressin) receptor antagonist a Hyponatremia results from an increase in circulating AVP and /or increased renal sensitivity to AVP , combined with an intake of free water A notable exception is hyponatremia due to solute intake AVP preserves Blood pressure via vascular and baroreceptor V1A receptor Increases water reabsorption via renal V2 receptors AVP antagonists are Vaptans Conivaptan The only intravenous vaptan Mixed V1A/V2 antagonist (Option B is correct)

Highyeild:

Modest risk of hypotension due to V1A receptor inhibition Liberalization of fluid restriction – mandatory

Extraedge:

Vasopressin (AVP) is synthesized in magnocellular neurons within the hypothalamus Half-life of AVP → 10–20 min

questions.text: What is the quantity of fluid present in the interstitial space in a normal healthy 30-year-old male with no known comorbidities, with a height of 160cm and weighing 60kg?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

9litres TBW Comprises 50% of body weight in w omen and 60% in men Total-body water (TBW) is distributed in TWO major compartments: Intracellular (intracellular fluid [ICF]) – 55–75% (2/3 rd ) Extracellular (extracellular fluid [ECF] – 25–45% (1/3 rd ) The ECF is further subdivided into: Intravascular (plasma water) (1/3 rd ) Extravascular (interstitial) space 2/3 rd TBW in males = 60% of weight = 60/100 x 60 = 36 litres Interstitial fluid is a component of ECF. ECF = 1/3rd of the TBW → 1/3 X 36 = 12 litres nterstitial fluid volume (IFV) = 2/3 X ECF = 2/3 X 12 → 8 litres The nearest answer here is 9L ( Option A) In some instances: Interstitial fluid volume (IFV) = 3/4 X ECF = 3/4 X 12 → 9 litres

Highyeild:

Fluid movement between the intravascular and interstitial spaces is determined by Starling forces Major ECF particles are Na+, Cl– and HCO3 – Major ICF particles are K+ and organic phosphate esters (ATP, creatine phosphate and phospholipids)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. This is the total body water Option: C. This is the volume of the intracellular fluid Option: D. this is the total ECF volume

Extraedge:

Above solutes determine the “tonicity” or effective osmolality of that component – Effective osmoles

questions.text: A 46 year old male k/c/o T2DM since 10 years presents with a history of fatigue, polyuria, and polydipsia for one week. His GRBS is found to be 540 mg/dl. Serum Sodium is 130 meq/l Serum potassium is 3. 5 meq/l, BUN is 28 mg/dl and S creatinine is 1. 4 mg/dl. Urine ketones are negative. What is the plasma osmolality in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

300 mosm/kg This patient has likely presented with a Hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state. HHS is an acute severe disorder primarily seen in individuals with type 2 DM exist along a continuum of hyperglycemia, with or without ketosis Profound dehydration with volume depletion , hyperosmolality, acid–base disturbances, hypotension, tachycardia, and altered mental status . Calculation of Plasma osmolality (Posm): Posm = 2Na + Glucose + BUN (all in mmol/L) OR Posm = 2Na + Glucose/18 + BUN/2.8 (glucose and BUN are in mg/dl) Posm = 2 x 130 + 540/18 + 28/2.8 = 300 mosm/kg ( Option B is correct )

Highyeild:

Normal plasma osmolality → 280 - 295 mOsm/kg AVP secretion is stimulated as systemic osmolality increases above a threshold level of 285 mOsm/kg

Extraedge:

HHS has a substantially higher mortality rate than DKA. Lower levels of counterregulatory hormones and free fatty acids. Marked hyperglycemia (plasma glucose > 1000 mg/ dl]), hyperosmolality ( >350 mosmol/L), and prerenal azotemia

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented to the medicine OPD with a history of polyuria and polydipsia. GRBS is 95 mg/dl and HbA1c is 5. 2 %. 24-hour urine output is 4.5 litres. Urine osmolality is low and on MRI brain, the pituitary bright spot is absent. Which of the following statements is false regarding the hormone involved in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a nonapeptide ring with a disulphide ring and tripeptide tail

options.label: B
options.text: The most important physiological action is an increase in water excretion and the promotion of dilution of urine

options.label: C
options.text: It binds to the V2 receptor on the basal surface of the principal cells

options.label: D
options.text: Its secretion can be stimulated by nausea, acute hypoglycemia, smoking and glucocorticoid deficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. The most important physiological action is an increase in water excretion and the promotion of dilution of urine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The most important physiological action is an increase in water excretion and the promotion of dilution of urine This patient has presented with symptoms and signs s/o of diabetes insipidus Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a syndrome characterized by The 24-h urine volume > 40 mL/ kg body weight 24-h urine osmolarity is < 280 mosm/L (Dilute urine) AVP is a non-peptide composed of a six-member disulfide ring and a tripeptide tail. ( Option A is correct ) Stored in neurosecretory vesicles of the posterior pituitary. Brain MRI (T1 weighted images) show a hyperintense signal normally emitted by the posterior pituitary This “bright spot” is a function of pituitary stores of AVP. Abnormally small or absent spot → Pituitary DI. AVP preserves Blood pressure via vascular and baroreceptor V1A receptor Increases water reabsorption via renal V2 receptors ( Option B is wrong and Option C is correct ) AVP secretion also can be stimulated by ( Option D is correct ) Nausea Acute hypoglycemia Glucocorticoid deficiency Smoking Hyperangiotensinemia

Highyeild:

Vasopressin (AVP) is synthesized in magnocellular neurons within the hypothalamus Aquaporin-2 water channels are inserted into the apical surface of the cell.

Extraedge:

Average set point , for AVP release corresponds to a Plasma osmolarity of → 275 mosmol/L Sodium level of → 135 meq/L Other actions of AVP Contraction of smooth muscle in blood vessels (skin and GIT) Induces glycogenolysis in the liver Enhance (ACTH) release by corticotropin-releasing factor

questions.text: A 48 year old male, a marathon runner , presents with altered mental status and dehydration. His heart rate is 110 bpm and BP-94/60mmHg. There is no oedema. His serum sodium level is found to be 155 meq/l. Further laboratory investigations done are as follows Serum potassium 3.6meq/l Serum chloride 104 meq/l Urine osmolarity -1100 mosm/kg Urine sodium 10 meq/l RBS-180 mg/dl BUN-28 mg/dl Serum creatinine-1.1mg/dl Which among the following is NOT a possible cause for his electrolyte imbalance?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus This patient has hypernatremia. Hypernatremia à increase in the plasma Na+ concentration to >145 mM Combined water and electrolyte deficit, with losses of H2O in excess of Na+ as with the above-mentioned patient. Increased Insensible losses of water due to exercise and heat exposure as with this patient (Marathon runner) High Urine osmolality (>800 mosm/kg) → Extrarenal losses Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Increased Insensible water loss Option: B. GI loss Option: D . Decreased water intake Increased sodium intake Low urine osmolality (< 800 mosm/kg) → Renal losses Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic) ( Option C is wrong ) Osmotic diuresis (glucose, mannitol, urea, etc)

Highyeild:

Points in favour of Extrarenal losses Increase in circulating AVP Urine volume < 500 ml/d Urine osmolality > 800 mOsm/kg (Maximally concentrated urine)

Extraedge:

Hypernatremic patients with NDI (Nephrogenic DI) Have high serum levels of AVP and copeptin. Low urine osmolality will fail to respond to DDAVP.

questions.text: A 38 year old male is admitted to the ICU with a head injury and is started on treatment for the same. On the 3rd day of ICU stay he develops hypernatremia-serum sodium is 156 meq/l His 24-hour urine output is 3. 5 L and his urine osmolality is 400 mosm/kg. What is the cause of hypernatremia in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mannitol administration This patient has presented with polyuria, hypernatremia with a low urine osmolality (Dilute urine) Hypernatremia with low urine osmolality → Differentials are: - Diabetes insipidus (DI) - Osmotic diuresis Osmotic diuresis results in excessive excretion of Na+Cl–, glucose, and/or urea. Differentiating between DI and osmotic diuresis as the cause of hypernatremia: Urine osmolar excretion rate is to be calculated Urine osmolar excretion rate = 24 hr urine output x urine osmolality Urine osmolar excretion rate >750 - 1000 mosm/kg → Osmotic diuresis Urine osmolar excretion rate is < 750-1000 mosm/kg → Diabetes insipidus In this patient, the osmolar excretion rate = 3. 5 x 500 = 1750 mosm/kg Here osmolar excretion rate is >1000 mosm/kg → osmotic diuresis In this patient of the head injury he is probably on IV Mannitol → Osmotic diuresis → Hypernatremia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . The urine osmolar excretion rate will be >1000 mosm/kg Option: C . It will present with a high urine osmolality of >800 mosm/kg Option: D . It will present with a high urine osmolality of >800 mosm/kg

questions.text: A 42 year old female presented with the history of polyuria and polydipsia for the last 2 months. 24-hour urine volume was found to be 3. 2l/day. Her Hba1c is 5. 2%. Her random copeptin levels were found to be 14. 5 pmol/l and stimulated copeptin levels were found to be 2.5 pmol/l. What is the likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Central diabetes mellitus There are 3 main types of polyuria polydipsia syndrome, namely, central diabetes insipidus, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and primary polydipsia. In addition, gestational diabetes insipidus can occur owing to increased arginine vasopressin metabolism during pregnancy. Copeptin, the C-terminal segment of the arginine vasopressin prohormone, is an easy-to-measure arginine vasopressin surrogate. Copeptin can be used as a reliable biomarker to discriminate between different forms of the polyuria polydipsia syndrome, therefore the osmotic stimulated copeptin levels will probably replace the classical water deprivation test in the future. Copeptin measurement upon osmotic stimulation with hypertonic saline or upon nonosmotic stimulation improves the differential diagnosis of diabetes insipidus. Treatment of central diabetes insipidus includes Desmopressin which is the treatment of choice, in oral or nasal form. Now, as per the algorithm shown above, This patient has a random copeptin <21.4 pmol/l With a stimulated copeptin level of <3.8 pmol/l Therefore this is a case of central diabetes insipidus

Highyeild:

Hypernatremic patients with NDI → High serum AVP and copeptin. Low urine osmolality failing to respond to DDAVP. Level of circulating AVP will help differentiate the underlying cause, i.e., NDI versus central DI.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . It will have random copeptin level >21.4 pmol/l Option: C. primary polydipsia will have stimulated copeptin levels >3.8pmol/l Option: D . Patient has a normal Hba1c which excludes this option.

Extraedge:

In pregnant patients, AVP assays should be drawn in tubes containing the protease inhibitor 1,10-phenanthroline to prevent in vitro degradation of AVP by placental vasopressinase.

questions.text: A 45 year old presents with a recent history of polyuria and polydipsia. Serum sodium is found to be 150 meq/l and urine osmolality is 200 mosm/L. There is only a 10% increase in urine osmolarity after administration of desmopressin. All of the following can cause this condition EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic meningitis Central DI Decreased level of AVP Decreased level of Copeptin Urine osmolality responding to DDAVP Nephrogenic DI Increased level of AVP Increased level of Copeptin Low urine osmolality failing to respond to DDAVP Increasing by < 50% or < 150 mosm/kg from baseline In this patient of hypernatremia with low urine osmolality, the increase in urine osmolality after giving DDAVP is only 10 % → nephrogenic DI Nephrogenic DI – Causes: a) Drugs: Lithium (Option A) Demeclocycline (Option B) Methoxyflurane Amphotericin B (Option C) b) Metabolic : Hypercalcemia Hypercalciuria Hypokalemia Remaining causes are given in the image below: Narrow definition of NDI: water permeability of the collecting duct not increased by AVP Congenital (idiopathic) Hypercalcemia Hypokalemia Drugs Lithium Demeclocycline Amphotericin B Methoxyflurane Diphenylhydantoin Nicotine Alcohol Broad definition of NDI: defective medullary countercurrent function Renal failure, acute or chronic (especially interstitial nephritis or obstruction) Medullary damage Sickle-cell anemia and trait Amyloidosis Sjögren syndrome Sarcoidosis Hypercalcemia Hypokalemia Protein malnutrition Cystinosis Chronic meningitis causes central diabetes insipidus and hence is not a cause for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

questions.text: A 48 year old female is admitted to the ICU following an RTA where she sustained a head injury. She was started on anti-oedema measures. On the 2nd day of her stay in the ICU, she develops hypernatremia. Serum sodium is 150 meq/l. Her weight is 60 kg. Lab investigations are as follows What is the ongoing water loss in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 litres This is a patient of hypernatremia secondary to anti-oedema measures (Likely IV mannitol) Calculation of urinary electrolyte-free water clearance is required to estimate daily, ongoing loss of free water which should be replenished daily. The urine-to-plasma electrolyte ratio ( urinary [Na+] + [K+]/plasma [Na+]) can be exploited as a quick indicator of electrolyte-free water excretion. Ongoing water losses is calculated using the formula for free water clearance (C,H₂O) CH₂OVX ( 1- U+UK ) Plasma Na Where V-is urinary volume UNa-Urinary sodium Uk-Urinary potassium So, CeH2O = 3000 x (1-30+20) 150 - 3000 X (1-50/150) = 2000 ml= 2 litres Therefore the ongoing water loss in this patient is 2 litres Other options a,c,d are wrong numerical values

Highyeild:

The urine-to-plasma electrolyte ratio can also be useful in hyponatremia . Ratio of >1 → Water restriction → <500ml/day Ratio of 1 → Water restriction → 500–700 mL/d Ratio of < 1 → Water restriction → < 1 L/day

questions.text: A 45 year old male, weighing 70kg, is admitted with altered sensorium. His serum sodium is 160 meq/l. His 24 hr urine output is 3 litres and Urine sodium is 20 meq and Urine potassium is 10 meq. What is the total water loss in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

9.1 litres Total water loss = Free water loss + insensible water loss + ongoing water loss Free water loss =TBW ( Na*- 140 ) 140 = 0.6 x 70 (160-140/140) = 42 (20/140) = 6 litres Insensible loss = 10ml / k * g / d * ay = 10 * 70 = 700ml Ongoing water loss = Volume of urine x ( 1- Urine Na + Urine K+) Plasma Na+ = 3000*( 1 - 20 + 10 160) = 3000 x 130/160=2437.5ml =~2.4 litres There total water loss- Free water loss + insensible water loss + ongoing water loss = 6litre +0.7litres-2.4litres = 9.1 litres So, total water loss is 9.1 litres

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . It is the free water deficit Option: B. It is the insensible water loss Option: C. It is the ongoing water loss

questions.text: A 38 year old male, a known case of bipolar disorder, receiving Lithium complaints of polyuria and polydipsia. His serum Sodium is 152 meq/l and his urine osmolality is 300 mosm /kg. A diagnosis of nephrogenic DI(NDI) due to Lithium is considered. Which of the following drugs can be used in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amiloride This patient has developed Nephrogenic DI with hypernatremia secondary to lithium consumption. Acute management: Replenishing ongoing free water losses By calculation of urinary electrolyte-free water clearance to estimate daily, ongoing loss of free water Chronic management: 1) Amiloride (ENaC inhibitor) 2.5 – 10 mg/d Decreases entry of lithium into principal cells à Decreases polyuria 2) Thiazides Induces hypovolemia and increases proximal tubular water reabsorption. 3) NSAIDs have been used to reduce the negative effect of intra-renal prostaglandins on urinary concentrating mechanisms

Highyeild:

Patients with central DI should respond to the administration of intravenous, intranasal, or oral DDAVP. Risk → NSAID-associated gastric and/or renal toxicity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - It is a potassium-sparing diuretic with no role in the management of NDI Option B - It is a loop diuretic with no role in the management of NDI Option D - Intravenous, intranasal or oral DDAVP is used in central DI.

Extraedge:

Lithium causes NDI by direct inhibition of renal glycogen synthase kinase 3 ( GSK3 ) GSK3 is required for the response of principal cells to AVP.

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida at 34 weeks POG complains of polyuria and polydipsia. She is found to have hypernatremia and low urine osmolality. What drug can be used in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DDAVP Gestational diabetes insipidus (DI ) Rare complication of pregnancy Develops in the third trimester Remits spontaneously 4–6 weeks post-partum. Caused by excessive vasopressinase activity Vasopressinase is expressed by placental trophoblasts It metabolizes AVP → Reduced circulating AVP → Polyuria Treatment: DDAVP (desmopressin) Resistant to vasopressinase enzyme.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Lithium is itself a cause of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and is not used in the treatment of gestational DI Option: B. Amiloride is used in the treatment of lithium induced DI
